title: Day 1372
content:
# Day 1372

**The "Mucus & Minimalism" Manifesto**

I am currently vibrating at the frequency of a damp basement.

I'm not "hospital sick." I'm not "dramatic Victorian orphan" sick. I'm "I just spent $7 on a bag of cough drops that taste like weird herbs" sick. My chest feels like a used lint trap, and my head is a balloon filled with lukewarm gazpacho.

Who did this to me? It's a whodunnit of poor choices. Was it the sudden Arctic plunge of the city air? Was it my Father-in-law, a man who is also dealing with a cold? Or was it the three too many light beers I had last Thursday and Friday, while bopping around the big apple catching up with old college friends?

The answer is yes. All of it.

**The Great Health Amnesia**

It's funny how the human brain works. When I can breathe through both nostrils, I am an ungrateful god. I walk around taking deep, luxurious gulps of oxygen without saying "thank you" once. I am a titan of industry. I am invincible.

But the moment my chest feels like I swallowed a handful of rusty thumbtacks? Suddenly, I'm a philosopher. I'm lying on the sofa staring at the ceiling, bargaining with the universe: "If you let me swallow a piece of toast without crying, I promise to be a better person. I'll spend more time connecting with my loved ones and less time scrolling. I'll stop ghosting my dentist. Please just heal me already this is driving me insane!"

Getting sick is the ultimate perspective-check. It's a forced software update for your gratitude.

**The Luxury of the "Boring"**

When you're shivering under three blankets, you start realizing that our "basic" lives are actually sci-fi levels of luxurious.

Hot water: A literal miracle that appears on command so I can wash away my sweat from working out in an air-conditioned gym.

AI: I can literally ask a computer to draw me a picture of a squirrel wearing a blazer, yet I complain if the Wi-Fi lags for three seconds.

![I threw in a Bitcoin tie and sunglasses, because why not?](https://miro.medium.com/1*RBO6UwMFWe76Gd4JsgaBSA.png)

The Fridge: A cold box of miracles that I stare into every twenty minutes, sighing because it doesn't contain a specific type of cheese I haven't even bought yet.

**The FOMO Virus**

The real reason we forget how good we have it isn't just because we're spoiled, it's because we're all addicted to the Digital Flex.

Social media is a curated museum of "W's." It's a never-ending parade of $80,000 kitchens, destination weddings in Tuscany, and cars that cost more than my overpriced college degree. Nobody posts a high-res photo of their "L's." You don't see a 4K Reel of someone's child sneezing on their appetizer or photos of the mounting pile of bills on their kitchen table.

Those of us on social media naturally find ourselves "pocket watching", staring into the wallets of strangers while our own lives are overflowing with stuff that would make a 19th-century king weep with envy.

**The Bottom Line**

No one ever scrolled their way to inner peace. Big Tech doesn't want you to be grateful; they want you to feel inadequate because inadequate people buy more stuff.

So, here's the silver lining of this chest-burning, snot-filled misery: It broke the spell. I'm too tired to care about your vacation photos. I'm too congested to worry about my neighbor's new SUV.

I'm just grateful for orange juice and the fact that I'm alive to complain about it. Happiness isn't having what you want; it's realizing that, even with a clogged sinus, you've already won the lottery. The fact we are alive at this point in time is literally a miracle. Glory be to God.

12/23/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
